mxCell.value:
Redirect to keycloak, 
if User is not authenticated

Action

An Action is a set of related sticky notes modeled top to bottom. It happens at a specific point in time.
The example shown here starts with a UI sticky. It represents a sign in form of our keycloak server. An "actor" sticky describes who can sign in. Basically, every user with a valid account.

The precondition for sign in is that a user wants to access prooph board, but has no access token. InspectIO is visualized as an external system here, because from the point of view of keycloak it is external.

document.label:
• email
  • password
  • display name
  • position

aggregate.label: Email is used as username. Needs to be unique.

mxCell.value:
Feature

The second frame type and therefor the second level of grouping is called Feature. Similar terms for Feature are Use Case or Activity.

Features group one or more related Actions and can be used to define tasks for developers. Usually, we discuss and design features in planing sessions, create tickets for each (in an issue tracker) and distribute work across the team.

Just like Bounded Contexts, details insight a Feature hide when zooming out.

Bounded Context

"In Domain-Driven Design, a large system is decomposed into bounded contexts, which become natural boundaries in code as microservices and as teams in the organisation." - Nick Tune

On prooph board you can visualize a bounded context by drawing a frame around stickies and features. If you zoom out, details will hide so you can view the context map. 

We use a keycloak Auth Server for Identity and Access Management. It's a natural system boundary, hence it's visualized as a separate bounded context on the board. Our value chain starts with the registration of a user. So we put the keycloak BC at the beginning of the timeline. 


Note: If you struggle with identifying bounded contexts, you can read this blog post by Nick Tune as a starting point to learn more: https://medium.com/nick-tune-tech-strategy-blog/modelling-bounded-contexts-with-the-bounded-context-design-canvas-a-workshop-recipe-1f123e592ab

Timeline

Model business processes along a timeline. Identify the value chain and sort activities accordingly

Note: You don't need to draw the timeline on your boards. Just make sure that everybody keeps it in mind: Change over time is modeled from left to right.
Welcome to prooph board! This is an example board illustrating some details of our service. You can use it as a reference when modeling your own business processes and workflows.

At prooph software we favor Domain-Driven Design to develop software focused on business needs. Modern software solutions should be flexible. The market changes fast and business has to adopt new strategies quickly. If product teams are not able to change software at the same pace, they drift away and cause significant cost if not the end of the business. 

Cross-functional teams, collaboration and experiments are key drivers to innovate and keep software and business aligned. We see Event Storming and Modeling as one of the best ways to achieve this goal. It can be used as a communication tool to discuss business problems, identify possible solutions and experiment with them. Last, but not least software developers can craft a domain model together with business experts, UX designers, key users and stakeholders without getting too technical. The resulting software truly reflects business and user needs. 

With prooph board you can digitize your storming. Model together in a (remote) team. Invite people to your board and try realtime collaboration. The "observing mode" allows you to follow colleagues across the board.

At first glance prooph board is comparable to other online whiteboards. But you'll recognize it's tailored to Design-Level Event Storming and Modeling. You probably know the Unix philosophy "Do One Thing and Do It Well". We truly belief in this philosophy and made it one of the key aspects of prooph board. 

General purpose online whiteboards are great for analyzing problems. You visualize information, do brainstorming, mind maps, etc.. But when it comes to solutions - especially when designing them in an agile and iterative way - most tools fail. This is where prooph board shines. We want to support teams doing continuous Event Storming and Modeling. 

A Big Picture Event Storming (on-site if possible, otherwise use prooph board for it, too), mixed with User Research and Story Mapping is a great starting point. Digitize the result and use it to design a domain model in small iterations.

Drag stickies from the left sidebar and drop them on the workspace. Stickies follow Event Storming semantics and color scheme. Below the sticky deck you can find a search bar and a context tree. Both help you navigate across the board once it becomes big.

    In the top right corner you see who is currently working on the board. Click on another person to observe them (remote collaboration is available in paid version only). 

    Via the menu you get access to an activity stream and import / export actions. 

    You'll find more of these orange text boxes on the example board. They give hints and explain the design.

"prooph board combines ideas from Domain-Driven Design, Event Storming and Event Modeling. It is not a new concept but rather an Interpretation of the three. We've built prooph board to support our daily work as a software company. We join product teams to accelerate  development and establish Event-Driven Architecture. The combination of DDD, Event Storming and Event Modeling has proven to be a very powerful and effective way to tackle complexity. And because we work remote and need to document our work, prooph board is a perfect fit." 
- Alexander Miertsch, CEO prooph software GmbH

Domain-Driven Design: by Eric Evans,  https://dddcommunity.org/
Event Storming: by Alberto Brandolini,  https://www.eventstorming.com/
Event Modeling: by Adam Dymitruk, https://eventmodeling.org/posts/what-is-event-modeling/

policy.label: If User is new then install first user board

mxCell.value:
Command

Blue stickies represent commands. With commands users (through UI), external systems (through API) and policies (if this -> then that) can tell the domain model to do something. Usually, commands are handled by aggregates (yellow sticky notes). If one command requires multiple actions you can use a policy (lilac sticky) to coordinate the actions. 

The "Install First User Board" feature is a good example:
We have a policy in the UI (it's a redux saga in case you know redux). The policy checks if a signed in user is new to the prooph boards context. If so, it sends a "Install First User Board" command to the backend. On the backend side two things need to happen now:

- Add User to the inspectio boards context
- Install a board with a default name for the user

To coordinate work, a "Install First User Board" policy (lilac sticky) handles the command coming from the UI. It sends two commands to the domain model with information added from system configuration:

Add User:
- User Id
- Initial Board Quota
- Initial Team Quota

Install Board With Default Name
- User Id

A command is basically a message sent from one system to another. Messages can be categorized. If you want to learn more, read the Messaging Flavours article by Mathias Verraes: http://verraes.net/2015/01/messaging-flavours/

Domain Event

Orange stickies represent domain events. They are facts along the value chain, named in past tense. When working with Event Sourcing, 
domain events are also the single source of truth. Every change in the system is recorded as a domain event. This gives you a full audit log and can be the foundation of an Event-Driven Architecture (EDA).

Naming events in past tense ease communication with domain experts. You can ask questions like:

- When is the board quota reduced?
- What should happen after a board is installed?
- ....

Such questions trigger discussions giving you deep insights of the domain. When doing exploration sessions with domain experts like a Big Picture Event Storming, it is recommended to focus on domain events. The example board shows a very detailed design (probably too much for most sessions with domain experts). The details are useful for developers to get a clear picture of the message and data flow. Those details can be added after an exploration session.The result of a Design-Level Event Storming session is the blueprint for implementation. See the slide deck "From Event Storming to Working Code" for details:   http://slides.com/prooph/deck/fullscreen#/

Designing domain events isn't always easy. Mathias Verraes has put together patterns for DDD and Messaging Architecture. It's a great source for advanced domain event design: http://verraes.net/2019/05/ddd-msg-arch/

mxCell.value: <font style="font-size: 24px;">1)</font>
<font style="font-size: 24px;">3)</font>
<font style="font-size: 24px;">4)</font>

Information

Information or data is everywhere. On prooph board every piece of data can be represented with a green sticky note be it: 

1) the payload of a command or event
2)  the resulting state after recording a new domain event
3) data fetched with a query for the UI
4) or additional information used by an aggregate to protect invariantes.

External System

Every system that is not part of the current bounded context is considered as external. This can be:

- A service in another bounded context
- An infrastructure component like a mail or socket server
- A third-party system like a cloud service
- An IoT sensor
- ...

It is important to know about every external system. Developing a connection to an external system is often hard to estimate. You only know if the documentation is good if you try its API.

External systems also define dependencies. This can be time based dependencies, for example you cannot finish a feature without the other team adding a new feature on their end as well. Or you have a runtime dependency like: If the external service is not available your own service will not work or need to use a fallback to serve requests and handle commands.

UI / API

With UI / API stickies you can describe the possible ways how users and external systems can interact with your domain model. The idea here is to use simple abstractions like icons rather than drawing complete views of UI screens. For the latter UI / UX designers have their own tools that are much better suited for the job. 

UI stickies are often accompanied by litte "Actor" stickies describing the role or persona who uses the UI.

mxCell.value:
Hot Spot

Hot Spots come into play when you discuss a problem or design a solution and you hit a question that can't be answered now. A Hot Spot acts as a reminder. You can also use it to mark To Dos or put a warning/alert next to a concept.

The sidebar search supports special filters. Try searching for "type:hotspot". The context tree will filter to show you exactly where hot spots are placed on the board. Click on one to focus it on the board.

Aggregate

Aggregates are part of the tactical Domain-Driven Design toolbox. If you never heard of aggregates before, you can read the introduction by Vaughn Vernon about "Effective Aggregate Design"   https://dddcommunity.org/library/vernon_2011/

There are many different approaches to design aggregates and some people also say they don't use the aggregate concept at all. Anyway, on prooph board it's basically the sticky note where you write down business rules. If these business rules are enforced by objects, put the name of the object above the rules, like shown here. The horizontal line can be added by clicking on the plus icon of the text format toolbar and then "Insert horizontal rule".

And as a reminder: OOP is all about encapsulation of data AND behavior: http://verraes.net/2014/09/objects-as-contracts-for-behaviour/

mxCell.value:
Policy

"If This Then That" summarizes a policy best. Usually, policies react on events and trigger new commands. It's the glue component, the process manager or the robot that drives automation.

As you can see on the example board policies can be the starting point for an Action, just like the UI / API stickies. If you think about it, it makes a lot of sense. A user can tell the system through a UI what to do next. An external system can do the same using a public API. When it comes to process automation, there is no external trigger. An event is recorded and the next process step needs to be triggered automatically. 
If This -> Then That.
<font style="font-size: 24px;">2)</font>

Redirect back
with access token

hotSpot.label: Will we have corporate accounts or only managed / on-prem offers?
We do not have an API yet. Limits need to be defined!

mxCell.value:
Plannings

The Subscriptions bounded context is not implemented yet. Hence, it is marked as planned (therefor it has a light yellow background). You can mark bounded context and feature frames as "important" (red bg), "planned" (yellow bg), "ready" (green bg) and "deployed" (normal grey bg) by right clicking on it and choose "mark as" from the context menu. It helps to coordinate ongoing work on a prooph board and the system under development.

The search supports look ups like "tag:planned" to filter all planned BCs and features.

As you can see, the context only contains some high-level domain events and a lot of hot spots with open questions. This can be the result of a first Event Storming session to explore a new problem. Step by step you add more details, play with different ideas and turn it into a blueprint for the implementation.

ui.label:
Board Workspace
Alert Message -> jump to Hot Spot -> remind again in: time

mxCell.value:
Parallel Timeline

Just like the "Subscriptions" context, "Project Management" and its preprocessor "Board Analyser" are marked as planned.

You may have noticed, that the two contexts are placed below "prooph Boards". The timeline for the two starts whenever a "Board Patch Saved" event is recorded in the "prooph Boards" context. From that moment on both processes run in parallel. 

Even though, users can be invited to a board at any time or an account can be upgraded, those activities belong to the same story (business process, value chain) and therefor have a place somewhere along the same timeline.

"Board Analyser" and "Project Management" on the other hand belong to a parallel sub process. It might even turn into a separate value chain. That's something we don't know yet, but putting them in a parallel timeline reminds us to further explore that idea.
